content: The "Helping Owners Mitigate Effectively Act of 2014" or the "HOME Act of 2014" delays flood insurance rate changes for 5 years after the enactment of the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012. The "HOME Act of 2014" delays flood insurance rate changes for 5 years after the enactment of the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012. Section 1308 of the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to cap the maximum annual chargeable premium rate for a property based on its appraised value. Additionally, a new section is added to the Internal Revenue Code allowing for credits on qualified flood mitigation expenses. The "HOME Act of 2014" delays flood insurance rate changes for 5 years after the enactment of the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012. A new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows for credits on qualified flood mitigation expenses, limited to $7,500 for qualified taxpayers holding flood insurance under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968. The term 'qualified taxpayer' excludes those with over 50 employees. Controlled groups are treated as a single employer. Qualified flood mitigation expenses are defined by FEMA. Partnership, S Corporations, and other pass-thru entities are included. For partnerships, trusts, S corporations, and other pass-thru entities, the credit and limitations are determined at the entity level. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for property subject to depreciation is treated as a general business credit. The personal credit allowed under subsection (a) is treated as a credit under subpart C. The credit for qualified flood mitigation expenses is terminated for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2022. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to reflect this change. The credit for qualified flood mitigation expenses will no longer apply to amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2022. The amendments made by this section, including Sec. 30E, will be effective for expenses incurred after December 31, 2012. Section 100236 of the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 is amended to include new funding sources for the National flood insurance fund. The Administrator may use additional amounts available to carry out this section. An alternative option is provided if the Administrator determines that the report. The Administrator may provide an alternative method for gathering required information if unable to submit the report on time. This alternative method must be notified to the relevant committees within 60 days of enactment. The gathered information using the alternative method must be submitted within 180 days of the notification. Upon submission of information required under the alternative method, the requirement under subsection (c) will be considered satisfied. SEC. 6. INCREASED FUNDING FOR MITIGATION PROGRAMS. Increased funding for mitigation programs includes $300,000,000 for predisaster hazard mitigation and $210,000,000 for flood hazard mitigation assistance annually from 2014 to 2018.
